item.title: Autoencoders
item.dc:creator: Katie Malone
item.description: Autoencoders are neural nets that are optimized for creating outputs that... look like the inputs to the network. Turns out this is a not-too-shabby way to do unsupervised machine learning with neural nets.

item.title: When is open data too open?
item.dc:creator: Katie Malone
item.description:
After all the back-patting around making data science datasets and code more openly available, we figured it was time to also dump a bucket of cold water on everyone's heads and talk about the things that can go wrong when data and code is a little too open. 

In this episode, we'll talk about two interesting recent examples: a de-identified medical dataset in Australia that was re-identified so specific celebrities and athletes could be matched to their medical records, and a series of military bases that were spotted in a public fitness tracker dataset.

Relevant links:

  • U.S. soldiers are revealing sensitive and dangerous information by jogging
  • The Strava heat map and the end of secrets
  • Strava's data lets anyone see the names (and heart rates) of anyone exercising on military bases
  • Re-identification possible with Australian de-identified Medicare and PBS open data
